repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - First, Second, and Third
            Programmatic Development Policy Loan for Sustainable
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, and Third
            Programmatic Development Policy Loan for Sustainable
            Development Project for Colombia were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low
            or negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the analytical work conducted as part of
            the Country Environmental Analysis (CEA) and in preparation
            for the first operation provided a thorough examination of
            environmental priorities and an understanding of the
            country's institutional framework for environmental
            management. The actual process of carrying out the analysis
            was equally as important, as it helped to build consensus
            among stakeholders on reforms to the National Environmental
            System (SINA). Inter-institutional coordination is essential
            for strengthening the reform program. Inter-institutional
            coordination, in particular National Planning Department
            (DNP) participation in the DPL Program has been instrumental
            in enhancing coordination among key SINA actors as well as
            other line ministries. This coordination among line
            ministries, as well as vertically between national and
            regional authorities, has enriched policy development in the
            areas of air quality, water quality, and environmental
            health, as well as data collection required for the
            monitoring of SINA's progress toward goals linked with
            sustainable development and the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Second Programmatic Development
            Policy Loan for Sustainable Development

abstracts.cdata!:
This document is for a Second
            Programmatic Development Policy Loan for Sustainable
            Development (SusDevDPL II) to the government of Colombia.
            This development policy loan (DPL) is the second in a series
            of three loans supporting the government's efforts to
            achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).
            Specifically, the program has the following objectives: (i)
            improving the effectiveness and efficiency of the National
            Environmental System (SINA); and (ii) integrating principles
            of sustainable development into key sectors, with a
            particular emphasis on protecting the most vulnerable
            groups. The program supports developing a results-based
            framework for planning and monitoring progress of the
            Sistema Nacional de Ambiente (SINA) toward goals directly
            linked with sustainable development and achievement o f the
            MDGs; improvements in inter-institutional coordination and
            increased public participation in decision-making; and
            preparation of critical policies and regulations related to
            air quality, water quality, solid waste management, and
            environmental licensing. The SusDevDPL Program has clear
            poverty implications, given that environmental degradation
            disproportionately affects the poor and most vulnerable
            populations, and thus increases inequality. Improvements in
            air quality, water quality, and hygiene in urban centers
            will lead to decreased morbidity and mortality from
            diarrheal diseases, acute respiratory illnesses and other
            health effects, and allow for reductions in avertive
            expenditures to address health risks. Increased
            accountability, transparency, and improved public
            participation will provide the most vulnerable groups a
            voice in environmental decision-making.
